facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 304/56 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 304/56. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 19, 1954 of Travancore-Cochin High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 5 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1954, of the former Travancore. Cochin High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 5 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SHAH J. on September 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-The Commissioner of Income Tax for Mysore, Travancore Cochin and Coorg at Bangalore 60 referred

facts.text: Appellants are a firm of merchants carrying on business in yarn in Districts of Trivandrum and Nagercoil in Travancore-Cochin State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are a firm of merchants carrying on business in yarn in the Districts of Trivandrum, and Nagercoil in the Travancore-Cochin State.

facts.text: For accounting year 1118 M.E. (August 17, 1942 to August 16, 1943), appellants submitted return showing net income of Rs.4,78,594-5-0 and were assessed thereon.

anchor.surface_text: For the accounting year 1118 M. E.  August 17, 1942 to August 16, 1943 , the appellants submitted a return under the Income Tax Act showing a net return of Rs.4,78,5945-0 as assessable income,

facts.text: Legislature of Travancore enacted Investigation Act in 1124 M.E.

anchor.surface_text: In 1124 M. E., the Legislature of Travancore enacted the Investigation Act companyferring authority upon the Government of Travancore to companystitute a companymission

facts.text: State of Travancore-Cochin merged with Indian Union on March 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Travancore-Cochin merged with the Indian Union on March 7, 1949, but the Income Tax Act and the Investigation Act companytinued to apply to that area

facts.text: Government of Travancore-Cochin referred appellants' case to Commission on August 6, 1949 under s.5 of Investigation Act.

anchor.surface_text: On August 6, 1949, the Government of Travancore-Cochin passed an order referring the case of the appellants to the Commission for investigation and report under s. 5 of the Investigation Act.

facts.text: Commission held in report dated February 1, 1950 that appellants made secret profit of Rs. 1,31,750 in 1118 M.E. not included in earlier assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence led before it, the Commission held by its report dated February 1, 1950, that the appellants had in the accounting year 1118 M. E. made a secret profit of Rs. 1,31,750 which was number included

facts.text: Commission computed tax payable on true income as Rs. 1,35,736-8-0 subject to credit for tax already paid.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission then proceeded to companypute the tax payable by the appellants and found that the amount of tax payable by the appellants on their true income was Rs. 1,35,736-8-0

facts.text: Government of Travancore-Cochin accepted Commission report and directed recovery on February 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Travancore-Cochin by order dated February 14, 1950, accepted the report of the Commission and directed that immediate steps be taken to recover,

facts.text: Income Tax Officer issued demand notice on March 15, 1950 under s.42 for additional tax Rs. 13,337-13-0 without fresh assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this direction, the Income Tax Officer, without holding any fresh assessment proceedings, issued on March 15,1950, a demand numberice under s. 42 of the Income Tax Act for the additional tax imposed on the appellants

facts.text: Union Legislature enacted Opium and Revenue Laws Extension of Application Act on April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Legislature enacted on April 17, 1950, the Opium and Revenue Laws  Extension of Application  Act providing for the extension of certain opium and revenue laws

facts.text: Government of India directed on October 25, 1951 under s.82 Investigation Act read with s.3 Opium Act that assessment proceedings be taken for concealed income Rs.1,31,750.

anchor.surface_text: Purporting to exercise authority under s. 8 2  of the Investigation Act read with s. 3, cl.  c , of the Opium and Revenue Laws  Extension of Application  Act, 1950, the Government of India, on October 25, 1951,

facts.text: Commissioner of Income Tax withdrew demand notice dated March 15, 1950 on January 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On January 1, 1952, the Commissioner of Income Tax withdrew the numberice of demand dated March 15, 1950, and thereafter the Income Tax Officer companymenced

facts.text: Income Tax Officer commenced reassessment and ordered payment of tax on concealed income by order dated March 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the Income Tax Officer companymenced reassessment proceedings against the appellants and by his order dated March 29, 1952, directed the appellants to pay income-tax

facts.text: Reference made to High Court under s.85 Investigation Act on three questions.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellants, a reference was made to the High Court of Travancore-Cochin under s. 8 5  of the Investigation Act and the three questions set out hereinbefore

facts.text: High Court answered the three questions in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the three questions in the affirmative. Against the order of the High Court answering the reference, this appeal has been preferred with special leave.

facts.text: High Court held there was evidence before Commission for its conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: ID the view of the High Court, there was evidence on which the Commission companyld arrive at the companyclusion recorded by it.

facts.text: Appellant contends Central Government can direct only on report of Central Commission, not State Commission.

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Viswanatha Sastri appearing on behalf of the appellants companytests that view on two grounds  1  that the Central Government may direct proceedings to be taken under the Income Tax Act only if the report was made by a companymission

facts.text: Appellant contends after State Government action, Central Government cannot act again under s.82.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that the Travancore-Cochin Government having once taken action directing recovery of the tax due, it was number companypetent to the Central Government under s. 8 2

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court right in answering the three questions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore in our judgment right in recording its answers on the three questions submitted by the Commissioner of Income Tax.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government may direct proceedings to be taken under the Income Tax Act only if the report was made by a commission appointed under the Taxation on Income Investigation Commission Act, XXX of 1947, and not on a report made by a commission appointed by the Travancore-Cochin State under the Investigation Act?

Whether the Travancore-Cochin Government having once taken action directing recovery of the tax due, it was competent to the Central Government under s. 82 of the Investigation Act again to take any action on the report?
Whether there is anything in s. 82 which prevents rectification of an unauthorised direction given under s. 82?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation within the structure of the Investigation Act; report contemplated is that of the State-appointed Commission

holdings.text: By s. 3 of the Opium and Revenue Laws Extension of Application Act, XXXIII of 1950, the Investigation Act continued to remain in force with the modification that reference in the State law to the State Government was in relation to income other than agricultural income, to be construed as a reference to the Central Government
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.3(c) Opium Act substitutes Central Government for State Government references post-extension

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.42 demand without fresh assessment invalid; tax liability requires proper assessment order under Income Tax Act

holdings.text: there is nothing in s. 82 which justifies the contention that action may be taken thereunder only once. If an unauthorised direction is given under s. 82, there is nothing in that provision which prevents rectification of that order
holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual bar in s.82 to multiple directions or rectification of defective prior state action
